title: 103_hr4897
content: The "Child Support Enforcement Act of 1994" allows for the seizure of lottery winnings, settlements, payouts, and sale of forfeited property to pay child support arrearages. Section 466(a) of the Social Security Act is amended to include procedures for imposing a lien on lottery winnings or gambling payouts to pay child support arrearages. The distributor must suspend payment, withhold the arrearage amount, and pay it to the child support agency. The amended Section 466(a) of the Social Security Act requires the suspension of payment, withholding of arrearage amounts, and payment to the child support agency from insurance policies or claim settlements. The amended Section 466(a) of the Social Security Act mandates the suspension of payment, withholding of arrearage amounts, and payment to the child support agency from insurance policies or claim settlements. In cases of awards, judgments, or settlements, the payor must suspend payment until verifying if the recipient owes child support arrears, then withhold and pay the arrearage amount to the State agency. If the State seizes property forfeited due to a criminal conviction, it must also follow similar procedures. If the State seizes property forfeited by an individual due to a criminal conviction, it must hold the property until confirming if the person owes child support arrears. If there are arrears, the State must sell the property, pay off other claimants, and deduct costs before paying the remaining proceeds or the owed amount. When property forfeited by an individual is sold by the State, the proceeds are used to cover costs and pay off other claimants. Any remaining proceeds or owed amount for child support arrears are then paid to the State agency for distribution. Payment is suspended until confirmation of arrears, and the amount withheld is paid to the agency if arrears exist. When property forfeited by an individual is sold, the proceeds cover costs and pay other claimants. Any remaining amount or child support arrears are paid to the State agency for distribution. Payment is suspended until arrears are confirmed, and the withheld amount is then paid to the agency. SEC. 3. RESTRICTIONS RELATING TO PROFESSIONAL, OCCUPATIONAL, BUSINESS, AND DRIVER'S LICENSES. Section 466(a) of the Social Security Act is amended to include procedures for State licensing departments to withhold licenses from noncustodial parents with outstanding child support warrants and individuals delinquent in child support payments until certain conditions are met. The State motor vehicle department can withhold driver's licenses and vehicle registrations from noncustodial parents with outstanding child support warrants until they resolve the issue. If a warrant related to child support is issued for an individual with a driver's license or vehicle registration, the department will require them to show why their license or registration should not be revoked. The State motor vehicle department can suspend driver's licenses and vehicle registrations of noncustodial parents with child support warrants. Individuals must demonstrate why their license or registration should not be suspended until the warrant is resolved. Temporary licenses or registrations may be granted until compliance with the order or warrant removal. SEC. 4. ATTACHMENT OF BANK ACCOUNTS. Section 466(a) (42 U.S.C. 666(a)) is amended to allow seizure of funds in a bank account to satisfy child support arrearages through an administrative process, with notice and opportunity to be heard for the account holder. If the seizure is not successfully challenged, the institution may pay the arrearage amount to the collecting entity. The amendment allows seizure of funds in a bank account to satisfy child support arrearages. If the seizure is successfully challenged, the institution may be required to pay the arrearage amount to the collecting entity from the account. SEC. 5 amends the Social Security Act to require courts to report child support obligations to credit bureaus. SEC. 6 addresses the liability of grandparents for financial support of their grandchildren. SEC. 6 amends the Social Security Act to make each parent liable for the financial support of their child if the individual is unable to provide such support.
